facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 310 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 310 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 22, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 183 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 22, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 183 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on May 21, 1959 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This appeal by special leave against the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India is limited to the question whether an order of reinstatement can be made on an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Appellant is a Jute Mill.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Jute Mill. There was a dispute pending before an Industrial Tribunal between a number of jute mills in West Bengal and their employees, and the appellant was a party to that dispute.

facts.text: Dispute pending before an Industrial Tribunal between jute mills in West Bengal and their employees; appellant was a party.

anchor.surface_text: There was a dispute pending before an Industrial Tribunal between a number of jute mills in West Bengal and their employees, and the appellant was a party to that dispute. During the pendency of that dispute, the appellant laid-off the respondent who was an employee in the ration shop maintained by the appellant from July 19, 1954, as rationing of food- stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant laid-off the respondent from July 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that dispute, the appellant laid-off the respondent who was an employee in the ration shop maintained by the appellant from July 19, 1954, as rationing of food- stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent was an employee in the ration shop maintained by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant laid-off the respondent who was an employee in the ration shop maintained by the appellant from July 19, 1954, as rationing of food- stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954. The reason for the lay-off was that the ration shop was closed following the end of rationing.

facts.text: Rationing of food-stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: as rationing of food- stuff came to an end from July 10, 1954. The reason for the lay-off was that the ration shop was closed following the end of rationing. This resulted in the staff in that shop becoming surplus.

facts.text: Ration shop was closed following the end of rationing.

anchor.surface_text: The reason for the lay-off was that the ration shop was closed following the end of rationing. This resulted in the staff in that shop becoming surplus. Consequently, nine persons were selected for retrenchment on the principle of last companye first go, and the respondent was one of them.

facts.text: Staff in ration shop became surplus.

anchor.surface_text: This resulted in the staff in that shop becoming surplus. Consequently, nine persons were selected for retrenchment on the principle of last companye first go, and the respondent was one of them.

facts.text: Nine persons selected for retrenchment on principle of last come first go; respondent one of them.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, nine persons were selected for retrenchment on the principle of last companye first go, and the respondent was one of them. The appellant also applied under s. 33 of the Act to the Industrial Tribunal for permission to retrench the respondent along with others.

facts.text: Appellant applied under s.33 of the Act to Industrial Tribunal for permission to retrench respondent along with others.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also applied under s. 33 of the Act to the Industrial Tribunal for permission to retrench the respondent along with others. Shortly before the application under s. 33, the respondent had applied under s. 33-A of the Act and.

facts.text: Shortly before s.33 application, respondent applied under s.33A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before the application under s. 33, the respondent had applied under s. 33-A of the Act and. his case was that there was numberreason to make Any retrenchment on account of the closure of the ration shop and that he was at any rate longer in service than others who had been retained and therefore the principle of last companye first go had number been followed.

facts.text: Respondent claimed no reason to make retrenchment due to closure of ration shop.

anchor.surface_text: his case was that there was numberreason to make Any retrenchment on account of the closure of the ration shop and that he was at any rate longer in service than others who had been retained and therefore the principle of last companye first go had number been followed.

facts.text: Respondent claimed he was longer in service than others retained; principle of last come first go not followed.

anchor.surface_text: that he was at any rate longer in service than others who had been retained and therefore the principle of last companye first go had number been followed. It was also said that the respondent had been laid-off as he was an active worker of the union and as such was number in the good books of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent claimed laid-off because active worker of the union, not in good books of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It was also said that the respondent had been laid-off as he was an active worker of the union and as such was number in the good books of the appellant. It was, therefore, prayed that the respondent should be allowed full wages and amenities since the so-called lay-off, which was numberhing more number less than retrenchment and that he should be reinstated.

facts.text: Respondent prayed for full wages and amenities since lay-off, and reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, prayed that the respondent should be allowed full wages and amenities since the so-called lay-off, which was numberhing more number less than retrenchment and that he should be reinstated. The Industrial Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the lay-off was justified because of the closure of the ration shop and gave permission to the appellant to retrench the respondent on the principle of last companye first go .

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held lay-off justified because of closure of ration shop.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the lay-off was justified because of the closure of the ration shop and gave permission to the appellant to retrench the respondent on the principle of last companye first go . The respondent appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal gave permission to appellant to retrench respondent on last come first go principle.

anchor.surface_text: and gave permission to the appellant to retrench the respondent on the principle of last companye first go . The respondent appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal. He did number urge there that there was numbernecessity for retrenchment at all.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal. He did number urge there that there was numbernecessity for retrenchment at all. What was urged there was that the Industrial Tribunal was wrong in holding that the principle of last companye first go had been followed in this case.

facts.text: In appeal, respondent did not urge no necessity for retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: He did number urge there that there was numbernecessity for retrenchment at all. What was urged there was that the Industrial Tribunal was wrong in holding that the principle of last companye first go had been followed in this case.

facts.text: In appeal, respondent urged Industrial Tribunal wrong on last come first go principle.

anchor.surface_text: What was urged there was that the Industrial Tribunal was wrong in holding that the principle of last companye first go had been followed in this case. The Appellate Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the respondent had been in service much longer than others who had been retained and therefore the principle of last companye first go had been violated.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held respondent in service much longer than others retained; principle violated.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the respondent had been in service much longer than others who had been retained and therefore the principle of last companye first go had been violated. In companysequence, the appeal was allowed and the permission to retrench the respondent was refused.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal allowed appeal, refused permission to retrench respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the appeal was allowed and the permission to retrench the respondent was refused. The Appellate Tribunal also ordered that the respondent, should be reinstated in service without any break in the companytinuity of service and the order of the appellant in laying him off and discharging him in effect from July 19, 1954 was set aside.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal ordered respondent reinstated without break in continuity of service.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal also ordered that the respondent, should be reinstated in service without any break in the companytinuity of service and the order of the appellant in laying him off and discharging him in effect from July 19, 1954 was set aside.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside appellant's order laying off and discharging respondent from July 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and the order of the appellant in laying him off and discharging him in effect from July 19, 1954 was set aside. Thereupon the appellant came to this Court and was granted special leave on the limited question set out above.

facts.text: Appellant came to Supreme Court and granted special leave on limited question whether reinstatement order can be made under s.33A.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant came to this Court and was granted special leave on the limited question set out above. In our opinion, the answer to the limited question on which the special leave has been granted can only be one in view of the language of s. 33-A.

facts.text: Lay-off resulted in discharge in effect from July 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: laying him off and discharging him in effect from July 19, 1954 was set aside.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 22, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 183 of 1955.

This appeal by special leave against the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India is limited to the question whether an order of reinstatement can be made on an application under s. 33-A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .
Thereupon the appellant came to this Court and was granted special leave on the limited question set out above.

arguments.claim: a complaint under s.33A is as good as a reference under s.10 and tribunal has power to order reinstatement if contravention of s.33 proved

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the answer to the limited question on which the special leave has been granted can only be one in view of the language of s. 33-A. That section lays down that where an employer contravenes the provisions of s. 33 during the pendency of proceedings before a tribunal, any employee aggrieved by such contravention, may make a complaint in writing to the tribunal and on receipt of such complaint the tribunal shall adjudicate upon the complaint as if it were a dispute referred to or pending before it, in accordance with the provisions of the Act and shall submit its award to the appropriate government and the provisions of this Act shall apply accordingly.

holdings.text: A complaint under s. 33-A is as good as a reference under s. 10 of the Act and the tribunal has all the powers to deal with it as it would have in dealing with a reference under s. 10, including the power to order reinstatement if the employee has been dismissed or discharged in breach of s. 33.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that a complaint under s. 33-A of the Act is as good as a reference under s. 10 of the Act and the tribunal has all the powers to deal with it as it would have in dealing with a reference under s. 10. It follows, therefore, that the tribunal has the power to make such order as to relief as may be appropriate in the case and as it can make if a dispute is referred to it relating -to the dismissal or discharge of a workman. In such a dispute it is open to the tribunal in proper cases to order reinstatement. Therefore a complaint under s. 33-A being in the nature of a dispute referred to a tribunal under s. 10 of the Act, it is certainly within its power to order reinstatement on such complaint, if the complaint is that the employee has been dismissed or discharged in breach of s. 33.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language of s.33A equates complaint to a reference under s.10, conferring full adjudicatory powers including appropriate relief like reinstatement for contravention of s.33 in cases of dismissal or discharge.

holdings.text: Counsel not permitted to argue that the action was lay-off rather than discharge or dismissal because special leave was granted only on the limited question of power to order reinstatement under s.33A.
